												FlatOut was released on November 5, 2004 for both Windows and Consoles. My first impressions of the game were also back then. The game was fun. But now, it can only be played for nostalgia. I suggest you pick it up on a sale. I said that the game was fun because there are better games out there that you can buy. This game made a good start for the derby racing game and started a future for FlatOut series. I still find it amazing how the driver just flies out of the window during big crash. The gave is hilarious especially if you play with friends. But I am not too sure if the game servers are even running. I know you can play with friends via some LAN programs or even HOTSEAT. It's a good game to have fun with. As in any racing game there must be music in this one. It has a decent soundtrack for the time of release, but I have personally never heard those bands in my life before or after. I do not dislike the soundtrack but I think it could have been much better. The rest of the sound effects seem fine and nothing particular caught my eye( or more like ear).  2004 was a big year for very good looking games. This game didn't do too bad compared to big fish around that time. Car detail is good. The detail of the maps is good as well. Human rag dolls are a bit on the low side, but they are not that important. Overall, I am still very happy with the graphics to the current time. 


FlatOut 
A Screenshot of FlatOut
By: Princess Gay X




Controls and overall steering is a bit funny. I take it that's because the game was made for consoles too. There are not many buttons to press, but powerful steering can ruin your race. 


Getting rkt 
A Screenshot of FlatOut
By: Princess Gay X




There are a few things, of course, that I quite hate about FlatOut. First thing is AI. It's so straight forward that it's actually not fun playing against computer. All it wants is to reach the finish line. I can also add that AI drives in the best possible way and will not crash. All other reasons add up to the first one. Because the AI drives really well, one mistake on the map could mean that you have lost your lead, quite probably for the rest of the match. And the last thing is that in my opinion the cars get damaged way too fast even without actually crashing into anything. But the end of the match you will end up having engine on fire, 2 car seats with human and skeleton of the car. 


My new ride 
A Screenshot of FlatOut
By: Princess Gay X




Re-playability is low in my opinion, because you can just play other better games with the same name. So in overall, I think this game (without considering the rest of the series at least) is quite good. I would recommend it simply because it's really fun. Not everywhere you can send the driver flying out.

												A lot of people seem to be writing nostalgia reviews (to the point where "nostalgia" is not only the main theme, but also the only noun present in the whole review). So here's a newcomer's take for a change.Flatout is many things, but firstly and foremostly it's a racing game. You buy a car, you race AI opponents, get money to buy upgrades, or better cars. Complimenting that you have various ridiculous - but apparently quite iconic - events, which range from demolition derby to a variant of darts where you crash your car into a solid obstacle at speed to hurl yourself through the windshield and onto a gigantic net which serves as the dartboard.The events, as popular among the fans as they seem, didn't really catch my attention - there's not really enough substance or strategy to any of them to please this Nofun McGee. No, I'm looking for nothing but pure driving, and flying through the windshield doesn't count as driving in my book.That's why I found Flatout really grating at first, even in the race mode. The game just loves putting a ton of heavy obstacles specifically where they belong the least, and this is not helped by the fact that you never wear your seatbelt, and that most tracks take place on very slippery surfaces, usually dirt, but if the game hears you complaining it will gladly offer some snow instead. Stomp your foot in despair and get ice. Little did it know, I'm not the type to get easily discouraged, but that didn't prevent it from keeping screwing me over. Once you learn how to powerslide slippery turns, it will "admit defeat" and give you asphalt tracks, where you have so much grip it feels weird, and makes you crash like never before. And then it goes urban, where against all racing game logic you crash into curbs as you try to navigate twisting streets at a speed, absolutely blocked from cutting any corners, and then it mixes it up with dirt roads so you have to switch between dirt thinking to asphalt thinking on the fly.If this all sounds kinda like a rally game, that's because Flatout kinda is a rally game. A rally game crossed with Burnout, where you have a boost gauge that increases by crashing into stuff, and opponents to crash into. The weird thing is that unlike Burnout, obstacles in Flatout aren't made of crepe paper. They are very solid, and as I said, you wear no seatbelt. At the same time, just like Burnout, you get boost from demolishing them. This might seem counter-productive at first, but in practice it means you can afford to screw up every now and then since it gives you a little bit of boost to compensate a little bit of lost time, unlike Burnout where screwing up isn't a big deal, boost is essentially free and is used to stay ahead of rubberbanding AI just before the finish line. Speaking of which, Flatout AI does not rubberband, and yet is still competitive. I know, right?Speaking of your opponents, in order to keep ahead of them you have to keep souping your car up. However, while the game does allow you to do some modifications that some other developers who aren't really into cars would never think of implementing, such as upgrading the exhaust for actual performance purposes rather than cosmetic, or the engine's flywheel to make it linger at high revs for longer, generally there's no real depth to the whole upgrade system. You just buy the upgrades one after another as they come, and the end result is basically a faster and more responsive car. There's no way to screw anything up. Can't say it doesn't do wonders for mass appeal, but I'd prefer a little bit more involved system, just adjusting suspension tightness with sliders and such would do, just to make my car really mine. That could also be helped with better cosmetic options than just 5 crappy paintjobs for each car, then again you're basically racing rustbuckets on dirt roads, not shiny chrome monsters in the streets of Tokyo.Towards the end of the game I was already mastering the roads, perfectly cornering in tandem with AI, never crashing and generally having a blast, much of which is credited to the options menu and it's cooperation in turning the music down. However, there came an overwhelming feeling of joyful sadness, like when you're done watching a really good movie and you're like "man I wish I could watch that again," when you remember that you can, except this is even better, because for your second run the game has an optional realistic mode that makes physics a lot more challenging.I was never happier flying through windshields before.

												While this game is very fun, it does have it fair share of problems. In some ways it feels a bit dated, but at the same time it holds up quite well. Which is not that surprising for a game that came out in 2005. The controls really make and break this game. They are very floaty and extremely clunky. It basically feel like you're controlling a jetski in rough waters. When on tarmac, it feels good. You can drift around corners and speed through light curves and it feels like a great arcade racer. When you drive on snow and off-road on the other hand, you're sliding all over the place and have little to no control. Almost slowing down completely before big corners in order to handle them. And the AI cars will drift through like zen masters. Which is another problem with this game. The AI. There's not much rubberbanding in this game. If one of the AI cars end up ahead of the pack, then their perfect path finding will leave you in the dust. You can never catch up. I had the fastest car with all upgrades, and they still sped ahead of me. This game is about crashing your opponents to get ahead, and then keep the lead. And if you crash yourself, you're forced to a 4 second slow-mo crash sequence, and when it ends you're put back quite a while. Usually last place. There's also a reset button. It works when prompted, and some other times as well. When you've been pushed off track and facing the wrong way though, it will most likely not work. You don't decide when to reset, Flatout does. But when it all comes together (usually the tarmac tracks) this game is incredibly fun. But the other aggravations kept me from finishing this game. I beat the bronze and silver tracks, but I had to give up at the gold tracks. After resetting a track 20 times because the AI kept using the PIT maneuver to turn me the wrong way, I gave up. That's where the fun ended for me. But for the price and for the hours I put in, I can't complain. I will recommend this game, but be aware that it definitely has its shortcomings. But then again, it's also a 9 year old game.

												10 years after this game's release.. it's... adequate. FlatOut is a game I used to play on the original Xbox. It's... a racing game, at least that's what it claims to be.If you played the game back in the day, what you probably remember most is the ragdoll effect the game has. You crash too much, and your driver flies through the car in a ragdoll. And if you remember that, you most likely remember the minigames involving your driver's ragdoll. The fun minigames include playing darts with your driver's body, seeing how far or how high you can make your driver fly, or flying into a clown, which I remember sucking at as a kid.Of course the game has it's flaws, which is understandable for a 10 year old game. And sadly, 70% of the game consists of it's worst feature; Racing.Now I'm not really much of a hardcore Nascar kind of guy, so I don't know how car parts work and how upgrades work and whatnot. But racing in this game is a frusturating mess. It was a mess back then, and it still is now. It's not as bad as the racing minigames on the older Grand Theft Auto games that were released around the time this game was new, but there's a large chance you'll be shouting swears and curse words from the racing. The opponents will always stay on the road. Sometimes they'll make a wrong turn and try to get back on track but they'll barely crash and wipe out. You, on the other hand, will find yourself slipping through sharp turns, flying off the track and wiping out from EVERYTHING. You'll feel like a feather in a race with a bunch of bricks, much like GTA III.If you've played the game for more than 30 minutes, you get this nagging feeling that the game was built for demolition. Like demolition derbies, which is available as a side "mission" to earn cash. Said cash can be used for upgrades.These upgrades suck.I don't know if I picked the wrong car, or if I'm just bad at this game but I had my car's body upgraded to, what claims to be, maximum protection. "Survive the harshest crashes" the description of the upgrade said, or something. And the car's pretty heavy too. Despite all that, I found my driver flying several feet across the map because I hit a TREE STUMP without crashing into anything else prior.You also get a little radio when you're in-game. The music.. is forgettable. This is coming from someone who enjoys more like Country and Pop, mind you. I enjoy some rock and to a lesser extent, heavy metal now and then but you'll be hearing songs about screaming teenagers or "babies with two heads". The baby song politely keeps the wonderful image in your head as the woman vocalist keeps screaming the phrase over and over again as an excuse for the chorus. The only song I really remember in a good way was "Beat the Boys" by Lab, which is used for the game's opening. I remember hearing the song play on the in-game radio, but it barely happens. I don't see a way to have custom music playing either, so that's another thing.Oh, and about the minigames I mentioned before; Only two of them are available at the start of the game. You have to unlock the rest from, I'm assuming, the good ol' racing. Yayyyy.The game is nice to pick up and play every now and then but I bet you 90% of the time, you'll only be playing the minigames. I'm sure there are other racing games with smoother.. well.. racing. Luckily, I remember on the Xbox, there being a certain phrase you type in as your profile name to unlock everything. I don't really remember it and frankly, I don't approve of cheating my way through video games. But if you don't have the patience to get through the racing, then you'll probably want to look it up. Honestly, I don't know whether or not to recommend this game, but it has a lot of nostalgic value to me and I can't really call it a "bad" game. I did have a lot of good fun times with the game back then. If you like a little goofy fun, then you should try the demo first. It's a lot better with friends to play with. The lack of the ability to save replays is a little disappointing though. (One time, my driver's foot got caught between the car and a wall, and stretched out mid-launch during the long jump minigame. I took a screenshot though.)

												One of the most broken and frustrating racers around.Some people will tell you that this game is difficult... It's actually one of the easiest racers that I can think of- when it doesn't troll you.  Just to check that I wasn't going crazy, I started taking a tally of every time I had to restart and how many of those were due to unforced error.  80% of restarts/crashes in this game are due to unavoidable circumstances.  80%.  Drift into a traffic cone?  Half the time you're fine, the other half your car flips.  Brush up against a barrier? Half the time you're fine, the other half you're ejected from the car- faster than your car was moving.  Press reset fifty times and eventually you'll be placed halfway back up the track in last place nowhere near where you were.Take away the frustrating and unfair crashes and resets (with a reset button that is completely broken) and you're left with a game that will take just a couple of hours to complete.  It's a shame too, because when it plays fair the drifting can be pretty good.  As a total package it's garbage.

												I really have mixed thoughts for this game... Essentially you race around in clunkers and beat up old muscle cars. The cars are supposed to handle like clunkers too, which they do. At least for the first couple of races. Once you're past like the fifth or sixth track, you'll realize that even though you're driving the same exact car with all the upgrades, all the AI cars start handling like exotics which doesn't seem right.  Second, this is one of those "make one mistake and you're done" racing games, if at any point you come to a complete stop you might as well just restart the track because everyone will get so far ahread if you weren't first..Another strange flaw is the  turbo/nitro system. The game will give you turbo not for driving good, but the opposate. Instead of getting boost for drifting corners successfully or maybe jumping something, it will give it to you for smashing things around you which seems really counter prodcuctive. If I slam through a stack of tires to get boost, the speed I've lost will is almost always more than the speed I'll get from burning all my boost. Also, most of the things required to get huge amounts at a time will slow you down almost to the point of stopping.Another huge flaw is the reset button. I find that I use it every single race. Want to drive through a fence or buliten board? sure smash it up. What about this wooden pole or small tree stump? Nope, that will wreck your car completely causing you to  need to reset. But, this wouldn't be as bad if the game didnt make you sit there and watch your driver ragdoll around for 3 seconds before you can get back on the track. On top of the 3 seconds you just lost watching your ragdoll, the game sets you back a pretty good distance away from where you wrecked. This alone will send you from a decent first to last in seconds.For me I just can't be happy and play this game with these flaws. I can drive like a boss the first couple laps then screw up once and be done for the rest of the race. If I cant get at least third then I just reset it because theres no money awarded below that. Now, I'm not saying I want the game to be super easy because this isn't a pull ahead and win game by design, It's just the objacts that you'd think would be breakable and arent, or having to reset the race because I crash at the last second and lose my standings, and the terrible reset, I just can't enjoy the game without getting mad. Now if you want to just get the game to drive backwards on the track and smash stuff or play the demoliton derby minigames, then get it, But if you want a fair driving game that you can have fun and progress in this isn't the game you want.

												This is a good example of a game that just doesn't know what it wants to be; the racing aspects of it actively contradict the demolition aspects, making it downright painful to play at times. All of the modes offered each somehow find a way to sap all of the fun out of flinging yourself from a moving vehicle.Graphics: The cars and terrain look decent enough for 2004; I'd even go as far as to say the damage effects look good. The skybox texture and the background look like they came out of the '90s, however. There is an issue with models and textures not covering the full extent of their physics, creating invisible walls or bits of physics objects. The UI is abominable and after extended play it can begin warping itself around the world; it's difficult to explain, but it appears that physics are applied to the UI and it can glitch out, causing display issues.Sound: The sound effects, particularly the car sounds, seem very budget and hollow, as if they were recorded on a $20 tape recorder from the 80's. The soundtrack itself though, is actually pretty good; most of the tracks fit the game well enough.Gameplay: Your driver seems only too eager to launch himself through the windshield at the slightest brush from a sapling. Sure, it's funny the first couple of times, but when it gets right down to it, this game's poor physics and driver launching feature get in the way of both racing and, to a slightly lesser extent, the "Bonus" modes (which include a counterintuitive demolition derby in which you keep your car from getting smashed, and things like darts and bowling which utilize your driver being launched from the vehicle). The vehicle customization is scant and performance options are as vague as those of the Need for Speed games of the era.Conclusion: The main selling point of FlatOut proves to be little more than a tacked on gimmick to what is ultimately an average racer that seems to have assigned itself the task of trying to make losing funner and easier. If that sounds appealing to you then by all means go for it, otherwise, skip it.This Reviewer Gives FlatOut: 4/10

												Utterly disappointing.I seriously cannot recommend this at all. This game just flops, specially compared to its successor. Ignore this and get FlatOut 2 instead.Flaws:• The cars feel weightless. You barely nudge a curb going 15 and your car just tumbles. You slam into another car and it doesn't really feel like you've done anything to it.• Cars have no grip/traction, you seem to be constantly sliding along. This would be fine on snowy tracks, but not on every track. Braking basically has no effect, trying to slow down before a hairpin turn and NOPE! just keep on sliding off the course!• Courses are very bland. They are wide and empty feeling with no character to them. Theres also very little in the way of different paths/shortcuts.• You get flung from your car if you barely tap anything.. most of the time. The game is really inconsistent as to what makes you get flung out. Barely scrap a sign? AWAY YOU GO! Slam head on to another car? Nah, you're fine!• Its a Demolition game.. WHERE I ACTIVELY DO NOT WANT TO CRASH, EVER. With how easy it is to be tossed out of your car, theres no point in going after the other racers. You get boost for crashing into things, but it also increases your odds of being thrown from your car, and the fact most things you can break to get boost are also very heavy when hit and will slow you down. Boosting is also something you'll only use to correct coming out of a turn, because going to fast and barely scraping something (and one time nothing at all) will send you flying!• If you drive ever so slightly off the course, even though you can easily correct yourself and get back on, the game will nag you to reset, often respawning you behind everyone else! With how slippery your car handles, this is more common than it should be.• The sound design is poor.. very poor. With how amazing it was in the 2nd game, I truly was surprised how crummy it is here.  There are almost no sounds for hitting things. Your tires are next to silent, with how slippery the cars already feel, the lack of sound makes the cars feel like they are floating. The engines sound weak, like you are driving a go-kart or lawn mower.• Unsatisfying driving. Managing to get a perfect run on a track felt more like a test of patience than skill.• Upgrades do nothing, atleast they feel that way. My thinking was to upgrade my tires and suspension to have better grip. Well it did nothing at all, the car was just and slidey as ever. You often feel like your car is under powered compared to the computer. Eventually after buying a few upgrades you can beat'em easily, even though the upgrades feel like they've done nothing at all to improve your car. You just suddenly starting keeping pace with the computer. There was no noticable increase in speed, durability, grip or anything.The few Pros it has:• The cars look nice again, being mostly muscle cars and having a nice demo derby look to them.... Now if they only sounded like muscle cars.• Music seems a bit better than the 2nd and there was a noticable amount of female vocals.• My controller worked on the menus! Not the way I would of liked it to, but it worked fine enough.While its not the worst racing game I've ever played, its certainly skirting the line. The game is at odds with itself, not knowing what it wants to be. Is it an arcadey smash everything demolition derby game? Its too easy to be pinged out of your car and everything you crash into slows you down. Or is it a technical driving sim? Well it has boosting, very simple upgrading and far to slippery controls. What does this game want to be?Ignore this and get FlatOut 2, they really improved EVERYTHING in the sequel.

												To start: I used to add a much longer header to these reviews, but since it often made the reviews too long to submit, I've opted to leave it on my Backloggery. Also, wear your seatbelts, kids. This game should be the reason why you do.Gameplay: I'm not too learned when it comes to racing games, but I do enjoy a good one from time to time. FlatOut is what I would consider to be a good racing game. Not a great one, but a good one at least. As you may or may not know, FlatOut is a racing game more in the vein of rally-style courses than Formula One courses, where there is a great deal of emphasis on vehicle control in rough terrain as opposed to hold down gas, turn wheel every once in a while. Yes, you will definitely need to make use of your brake button in this game, as well as maybe letting go of the gas every once in a while, as all the vehicles in game are rear-wheel drive. RWD means that you can do donuts. It also measn that you may find yourself doing donuts unintentionally. Since most racing games use front wheel drive, the physics in this game may feel unrealistic to some, but if you kinda know how a RWD car works, it's pretty solid actually.The game has an alright selection of cars, but honestly, you should just pick the car with the best power-to-weight ratio just as a matter of principle. This game also has a system of currency where you win races to get more dosh, and while it never turned into a grindfest for me, it might be if you're not as decent at racing games. Plus, the vehicles with the best PWR aren't really too much more expensive than the ones of the same class. Yes, there are multiple classes of cars in the game, which unlock one class at a time over the three series. While you can beat class two racers with a class one car, it becomes very difficult, and in some instances downright impossible. The way that you can kinda do this is through upgrades, which while a neat idea is also not that well executed, as you have to buy components through a series of parts (you can't just buy the best parts on their own; you've gotta buy the crap ones first). These parts don't transfer to other cars either, which just makes the system feel like a waste of time.The AI isn't exactly great, and if you've got an underperforming car, races can turn into an exercise in frustration as you have to take the track perfectly. There's no rubberbanding, which is good if you're absolutely smoking your opponents, but also pretty frustrating if you are way behind. AI in this game doesn't really have any aggression either; they just take the track as they want to, irrespective of you being in the way or not. This game manages to save a lot of file size by having only six maps where the tracks are different routes through the map. While the courses do for the most part feel their own (although there are a few lazy excuses for courses just being a course from earlier in reverse), you'll find yourself seeing a lot of familiar sights. Also, as mentioned earlier, this game is more along the lines of a rally racing game, so there's a LOT of start and stop. If that's not your thing, you may wanna look elsewhere.Overall, while this game could've done with some more work on tracks and the AI, it's still a pretty fun game overall. I managed to 100% the game with all gold medals in the amount of time that I've been playing it (~8 hours as of writing this review), and I don't regret my time. I just wish there was a bit more done for the single player. 7/10.Story: No story.Graphics: The game looks pretty great for a game from 2004, and it manages to have a good bit of detail for only being a 1GB download. The maps are big and constructed pretty well, things break in a satisfying way, there's a good deal of detail to the cars, and it all just looks good. While a realistic style does have a tendency to age absolutely terribly, from the perspective of a game from 2004, it looks pretty damn solid. There's no optimization issues for modern hardware either, as I was able to run it at a perfect 60 FPS with everything on max at 1080p. One issue that cropped up every now and then was that a magical fairy would show up every now and then and make the HUD go away and vomit the alphabet at me. Fortunately, this can be fixed temporarily by just Alt-Tabbing, so it's not a huge deal. Overall, the game looks pretty great for a 2005 game and not half bad for today's standards. Give it 20 years time though, and it may not look so great. 4/5.Sound: One big draw to this game for some is the amount of very obscure bands that this game has. Most of the bands are either of a punk or metal persuasion, but the metal only goes as far as something like a rip off band of Judas Priest. In fact, there's a few bands that sound like ripoff bands; there's a band that tries to be the Beastie Boys, one that tries to be every Industrial Band from the early 2000's, and one band that tries to be as terrible as possible (I still remember Killer Barbies' Baby With two Heads as being one of the worst songs I've ever heard from when I rented this game for PS2 back in '07). While it's not bad for the first few runthroughs and while there are still a few pretty good songs, it does get kinda tiresome after a few hours, so you're likely to just shut off the music and play your own. Sound design is delightfully chunky, and I still haven't gotten tired of the guy driver's derpy scream after being ejected from the car. Again, the problem with licensed music is that it's cool for a while, but it gets old really quick. 3/5.Overall scores are: 7/0/4/3; cumulative score of 7.0/10. Pretty fun racing game, and definitely a fun one to play with friends, but apart from that there's not much to it.

												To start: I used to add a much longer header to these reviews, but since it often made the reviews too long to submit, I've opted to leave it on my Backloggery. Also, wear your seatbelts, kids. This game should be the reason why you do.Gameplay: I'm not too learned when it comes to racing games, but I do enjoy a good one from time to time. FlatOut is what I would consider to be a good racing game. Not a great one, but a good one at least. As you may or may not know, FlatOut is a racing game more in the vein of rally-style courses than Formula One courses, where there is a great deal of emphasis on vehicle control in rough terrain as opposed to hold down gas, turn wheel every once in a while. Yes, you will definitely need to make use of your brake button in this game, as well as maybe letting go of the gas every once in a while, as all the vehicles in game are rear-wheel drive. RWD means that you can do donuts. It also measn that you may find yourself doing donuts unintentionally. Since most racing games use front wheel drive, the physics in this game may feel unrealistic to some, but if you kinda know how a RWD car works, it's pretty solid actually.The game has an alright selection of cars, but honestly, you should just pick the car with the best power-to-weight ratio just as a matter of principle. This game also has a system of currency where you win races to get more dosh, and while it never turned into a grindfest for me, it might be if you're not as decent at racing games. Plus, the vehicles with the best PWR aren't really too much more expensive than the ones of the same class. Yes, there are multiple classes of cars in the game, which unlock one class at a time over the three series. While you can beat class two racers with a class one car, it becomes very difficult, and in some instances downright impossible. The way that you can kinda do this is through upgrades, which while a neat idea is also not that well executed, as you have to buy components through a series of parts (you can't just buy the best parts on their own; you've gotta buy the crap ones first). These parts don't transfer to other cars either, which just makes the system feel like a waste of time.The AI isn't exactly great, and if you've got an underperforming car, races can turn into an exercise in frustration as you have to take the track perfectly. There's no rubberbanding, which is good if you're absolutely smoking your opponents, but also pretty frustrating if you are way behind. AI in this game doesn't really have any aggression either; they just take the track as they want to, irrespective of you being in the way or not. This game manages to save a lot of file size by having only six maps where the tracks are different routes through the map. While the courses do for the most part feel their own (although there are a few lazy excuses for courses just being a course from earlier in reverse), you'll find yourself seeing a lot of familiar sights. Also, as mentioned earlier, this game is more along the lines of a rally racing game, so there's a LOT of start and stop. If that's not your thing, you may wanna look elsewhere.Overall, while this game could've done with some more work on tracks and the AI, it's still a pretty fun game overall. I managed to 100% the game with all gold medals in the amount of time that I've been playing it (~8 hours as of writing this review), and I don't regret my time. I just wish there was a bit more done for the single player. 7/10.Story: No story.Graphics: The game looks pretty great for a game from 2004, and it manages to have a good bit of detail for only being a 1GB download. The maps are big and constructed pretty well, things break in a satisfying way, there's a good deal of detail to the cars, and it all just looks good. While a realistic style does have a tendency to age absolutely terribly, from the perspective of a game from 2004, it looks pretty damn solid. There's no optimization issues for modern hardware either, as I was able to run it at a perfect 60 FPS with everything on max at 1080p. One issue that cropped up every now and then was that a magical fairy would show up every now and then and make the HUD go away and vomit the alphabet at me. Fortunately, this can be fixed temporarily by just Alt-Tabbing, so it's not a huge deal. Overall, the game looks pretty great for a 2005 game and not half bad for today's standards. Give it 20 years time though, and it may not look so great. 4/5.Sound: One big draw to this game for some is the amount of very obscure bands that this game has. Most of the bands are either of a punk or metal persuasion, but the metal only goes as far as something like a rip off band of Judas Priest. In fact, there's a few bands that sound like ripoff bands; there's a band that tries to be the Beastie Boys, one that tries to be every Industrial Band from the early 2000's, and one band that tries to be as terrible as possible (I still remember Killer Barbies' Baby With two Heads as being one of the worst songs I've ever heard from when I rented this game for PS2 back in '07). While it's not bad for the first few runthroughs and while there are still a few pretty good songs, it does get kinda tiresome after a few hours, so you're likely to just shut off the music and play your own. Sound design is delightfully chunky, and I still haven't gotten tired of the guy driver's derpy scream after being ejected from the car. Again, the problem with licensed music is that it's cool for a while, but it gets old really quick. 3/5.Overall scores are: 7/0/4/3; cumulative score of 7.0/10. Pretty fun racing game, and definitely a fun one to play with friends, but apart from that there's not much to it.
